text.title: The Present Tense of Essere and Avere

sections.title: Present Tense of Essere and Avere

paragraphs.content: Like their counterparts in many other languages, the Italian verbs **essere** (to be) and **avere** (to have) are irregular. Here are the forms of the **present tense**:

As shown in the examples, it is not usually necessary to use the **subject pronouns** before the verb since the forms for the different persons are different – **sei** can only be **second person singular** (**tu**), **siete** can only be **second person plural** (**voi**), etc. Even with **sono**, the context always shows whether it means ‘**I am**’ or ‘**they are**’.
The pronoun is only required for emphasis, or to mark a contrast:

rows: I’m a doctor and he’s a teacher.
**Tu** **hai** una bella bici, ma **io** **ho** una macchina.
You’ve got a nice bike, but I’ve got a car.

paragraphs.content: The Italian **subject pronouns** are:
For the **third person**, the following pronouns can still be found in some texts, but are not normally used in contemporary Italian:
**Lui** (**third person singular** pronoun) replaces a **masculine** noun (like the English ‘**he**’); **lei** replaces a **feminine** noun (like the English ‘**she**’).

**Lui**, **lei** and **loro** are only used to refer to persons. In referring to objects, Italian normally avoids using the obsolete forms **esso**, **essa**, **essi**, **esse**, and omits the pronoun altogether:

rows: He is Paolo, she is Anna.

paragraphs.content: The **interrogative** is formed by adding a question mark at the end of the sentence:
The **negative** is formed by putting **non** (i.e. ‘not’) before the verb:

rows: We haven’t got any Italian friends.
**Non** **ho** la minima idea di cosa regalare a **Paola**.
I haven’t the slightest idea what to give Paola.

paragraphs.content: In Italian there is a **formal** way of addressing people which is used with people we do not know, or when some degree of formality is required. When the **formal** form is required, the pronoun used for the **singular**, for both men and women, is **Lei** (**third person singular**); the pronoun used for the **plural** is normally **Voi**, but in situations when a high degree of formality is required **Loro** can be used:

rows: Mrs Belli, have you got a driving licence?
Mr and Mrs Conti, are you Italian?
Mr and Mrs Conti, are you Italian?

paragraphs.content: There are some spelling mistakes involving **essere** and **avere** which are commonly made by learners; be careful to remember the following differences:
The verbs **essere** and **avere** are normally used as the verbs ‘**to be**’ and ‘**to have**’ are used in English. **Essere** is usually followed by an **adjective** or a **noun**:
**Avere** is normally followed by a **noun** (or a **noun** accompanied by an **adjective**):

rows: We have a lot of friends.
Paolo and I have got a car.

paragraphs.content: The verb **avere**, followed by a **noun**, is also used in a number of **idiomatic expressions** which correspond to English expressions using ‘**to be**’ followed by an **adjective** or an **adverbial phrase**:
**Avere** is also used in Italian to express age:
The verb **essere** is used in the expressions **c’è** (**there is**) followed by a **singular noun**, and **ci sono** (**there are**) followed by a **plural noun**:

rows: There are a lot of customers in the shop.

paragraphs.content: Note that **c’è** and **ci sono** are not usually emphatic. So, in the English sentences in paragraph 4.10, the voice stress does not fall on ‘**there**’, but on the **noun** that follows it (i.e. on ‘**letter**’, ‘**little/plenty of time**’, ‘**problem**’, etc.). Thus **c’è** and **ci sono** sometimes do not correspond to ‘**there is**’ or ‘**there are**’, as in the following examples:

rows: **C’è** **Luisa** al telefono. [i.e. she has just rung]
Luisa’s on the phone. [not: There’s Luisa on the phone.]
**Ci sono** **i tuoi amici** che ti aspettano. [i.e. they have just arrived]
Your friends are waiting for you. [not: There are your friends waiting for you.]

paragraphs.content: The **interrogative** is formed by simply adding a question mark at the end of the sentence, or with a ‘**question word**’ (see Unit 9):

rows: Is Professor Gatti there/anywhere/around? [i.e. I’d like to see/talk to Professor Gatti.]
Is there a lot of traffic?

paragraphs.content: The **negative** is formed by placing **non** before **c’è** or **ci sono**:
* In Italian the **double negative** is used: **non** + **nessuno**.
Note that in **negative** sentences giving general information, it is more usual to use the **plural** **non ci sono** than the **singular** **non c’è**.

exercises.instruction: Complete the following sentences using the correct form of **essere**.

exercises.title: Exercise 2: Verb Avere

exercises.title: Exercise 3: Essere or Avere
exercises.instruction: Taking the words in the two columns below, write negative and interrogative sentences using the verb avere.
examples: tu|fretta: Non hai fretta; Hai fretta?

items.question: **il professore | caldo**
items.answer: Il professore non ha caldo; Il professore ha caldo?

items.question: **la Signorina Berti | sete**
items.answer: La Signorina Berti non ha sete; La Signorina Berti ha sete?

items.question: **Lei [formal] | sonno**
items.answer: Lei non ha sonno; Lei ha sonno?

items.question: **Carla e Andrea | fame**
items.answer: Carla e Andrea non hanno fame; Carla e Andrea hanno fame?

exercises.title: Exercise 4
exercises.instruction: Taking the words in the two columns below, write affirmative and negative sentences using the verb essere.
examples: **io | italiana**: Sono italiana; Non sono italiana.

items.question: **il dottore | giovane**
items.answer: Il dottore è giovane; Il dottore non è giovane.

items.question: **la professoressa | simpatica**
items.answer: La professoressa è simpatica; La professoressa non è simpatica.

items.question: **Lei [formal] | alto**
items.answer: Lei è alto; Lei non è alto.

items.question: **le tue amiche | contente**
items.answer: Le tue amiche sono contente; Le tue amiche non sono contente.

exercises.title: Exercise 5
exercises.instruction: Imagine the things in the office; using all the words in the list, write sentences using c’è or ci sono.
examples: una scrivania: Nell’ufficio c’è una scrivania; quattro sedie: Nell’ufficio ci sono quattro sedie.

items.question: **tre computer**
items.answer: Nell’uff icio ci sono tre computer.

items.question: **tre finestre**
items.answer: Nell’ufficio ci sono tre f inestre.

exercises.title: Exercise 6
exercises.instruction: Imagine what is in the village; using all the words in the list, make affirmative or negative sentences, paying attention to the negative form (non ci sono + plural noun).
examples: tabaccaio, tabaccai: In questo paese c’è un tabaccaio, ci sono tre tabaccai, non ci sono tabaccai.

items.question: **museo, musei**
items.answer: In questo paese c’è un museo, ci sono tre musei, non ci sono musei.

items.question: **discoteca, discoteche**
items.answer: In questo paese c’è una discoteca, ci sono due discoteche, non ci sono discoteche.

items.question: **panetteria, panetterie**
items.answer: In questo paese c’è una panetteria, ci sono quattro panetterie, non ci sono panetterie.

items.question: **cinema, cinema**
items.answer: In questo paese c’è un cinema, ci sono due cinema, non ci sono cinema.

items.question: **biblioteca, biblioteche**
items.answer: In questo paese c’è una biblioteca, ci sono due biblioteche, non ci sono biblioteche.

items.question: **scuola, scuole**
items.answer: In questo paese c’è una scuola, ci sono due scuole, non ci sono scuole.

items.question: **ufficio postale, uffici postali**
items.answer: In questo paese c’è un ufficio postale, ci sono due uffici postali, non ci sono uffici postali.

items.question: **libreria, librerie**
items.answer: In questo paese c’è una libreria, ci sono quattro librerie, non ci sono librerie.

items.question: **giardino pubblico, giardini pubblici**
items.answer: In questo paese c’è un giardino pubblico, ci sono tre giardini pubblici, non ci sono giardini pubblici.

items.question: **ristorante, risk **
items.answer: In questo paese c’è un ristorante, ci sono sei ristoranti, non ci sono ristoranti.
